tit.e: Uji Shui Monogatari (literally, a collection of the Tales from Uji)

Uji Shui Monogatari (a collection of the Tales from Uji)
tit.cmt: タイトル用に変更しました。

sen.j: 宇治拾遺物語（うじしゅういものがたり）は、13世紀前半頃に成立した、中世日本の説話物語集である。
sen.e: Uji Shui Monogatari is a collection of setsuwa monogatari (narratives) of medieval Japan that was formed in the first half of the thirteenth century.
Uji Shui Monogatari is a collection of setsuwa monogatari (narratives) of medieval Japan that was compiled in the first half of the thirteenth century.
Uji Shui Monogatari is a collection of setsuwa monogatari (narratives) of medieval Japan that was compiled in the first half of the thirteenth century.

sen.j: 『今昔物語集』と並んで説話文学の傑作とされる。
sen.e: It is deemed as a masterpiece of setsuwa monogatari same as "Konjaku Monogatari Shu (literally, collection of Tales of Times Now and Then)."
It is considered a masterpiece of setsuwa monogatari, along with "Konjaku Monogatari Shu (literally, collection of Tales of Times Now and Then)."
It ranks with the "Konjaku monogatari shu" (Collected Tales of Past and Present) as one of the great masterpieces of setsuwa literature.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 編著者は未詳。
sen.e: Compiler or author is not known.
Neither the compiler nor the author is known.
Neither the compiler nor the author is known.

sen.j: 題名は、佚書『宇治大納言物語』（宇治大納言源隆国が編纂したとされる説話集、現存しない）から漏れた話題を拾い集めたもの、という意味である。
sen.e: The title means that this collection was compiled by picking up topics that had not been included into the issho (lost book) "Ujidainagon Monogatari (The Tale of Uji Dainagon (chief councilor)) (collection of setsuwa reportedly edited by Ujidainagon, MINAMOTO no Takakuni, not existing now).

The title means this collection was compiled by picking up topics that had not been included in the issho (lost book) "Ujidainagon Monogatari (The Tale of Uji Dainagon" (chief councilor)) (a collection of setsuwa reportedly edited by Ujidainagon, MINAMOTO no Takakuni but no longer in existence).

Its title refers to the fact that the setsuwa tales it contains were gleaned from those not included in the "Ujidainagon monogatari" ("The Tale of Chief Counselor Uji," a collection of setsuwa thought to have been compiled by the Ujidainagon MINAMOTO no Takakuni which is no longer extant).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 全197話から成り、15巻に収めている。
sen.e: It consists of 197 stories in total, and they are recorded in fifteen volumes.
It comprises 197 stories in 15 volumes.
It comprises 197 stories in fifteen volumes.
sen.cmt: 数字をスペルアウトしました。

sen.j: 古い形では上下の二巻本であったようだ。
sen.e: In its old form, it seems that the collection consisted of two volumes.
Apparently, the collection consisted of two volumes in its old form.
Apparently, the collection consisted of two volumes in its old form.

sen.j: 収録されている説話は、序文によれば、日本のみならず、天竺（インド）や大唐（中国）の三国を舞台とし、「あはれ」な話、「をかし」な話、「恐ろしき」話など多彩な説話を集めたものであると解説されている。
sen.e: According to its preface, it is explained that the stage of compiled setsuwa is not limited to Japan but covers three countries, Japan, Tenjiku (India) and Daito (China) and large variety of setsuwa such as "miserable" stories, "funny" stories and "horrible" stories.

The preface explains that the stage of compiled setsuwa is not limited to Japan but covers three countries, Japan, Tenjiku (India) and Daito (China), and that it includes a large variety of setsuwa such as "miserable" stories, "funny" stories and "horrible" stories.

According to the preface, the collected setsuwa tales are actually set in three different countries, not only in Japan but also in India and China; the preface also explains that the setsuwa tales have been collected into various types, including "aware" (poignant), "okashi" (amusing), and "osoroshiki" (terrifying) tales.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: ただ、オリジナルの説話は少なく、『今昔物語集』など先行する様々な説話集と共通する話が多い。
sen.e: However, the number of original setsuwa is not large, and many stories are common with various foregoing collections of setsuwa such as "Konjaku Monogatari Shu."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: However, the number of original setsuwa is not large, and many stories are common with preceding collections of setsuwa such as "Konjaku Monogatari Shu."
However, few original setsuwa tales were included, and many of the tales appear in earlier collections like the "Konjaku monogatari shu."
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: （説話の直接の出典には、『古事談』『十訓抄』『打聞集』などに類似の話が見られ、『今昔』との重出話にいたっては80余話もの数にのぼる）。
sen.e: (As direct sources of setsuwa, similar stories are seen in "Kojidan (Talks of the Past) ", "Jikkinsho (A Miscellany of Ten Maxims)" and "Uchigikishu," and over eighty stories are duplicates with "Konjaku."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: (As direct sources of setsuwa, similar stories are seen in "Kojidan (Talks of the Past)," "Jikkinsho (A Miscellany of Ten Maxims)" and "Uchigikishu," and over 80 stories are duplicates from "Konjaku."

(As for the direct sources for these setsuwa tales, very similar stories can be found in such works as the "Kojidan" (Tales of the Past), the "Jikkinsho" (Ten Miscellaneous Maxims), and the "Uchigikishu" (Collected Stories I Heard), and over 80 of its stories are duplicated in the "Konjaku monogatari shu.")
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 貴族から庶民までの幅広い登場人物、日常的な話題から珍奇な滑稽談など幅広い内容の説話を含む。
sen.e: It contains a wide variety of characters ranging from noble to common people and setsuwa with contents widely ranging from ordinary topics to curious comic stories.
It contains a wide variety of characters ranging from noblemen to common people, and the setsuwa have contents ranging from ordinary topics to curiously comical stories.
The collected stories feature a wide range of characters, from noblemen to commoners, and their subject matter ranges all over, from the quotidian to the bizarre to the hilarious.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 「芋粥」の話などは芥川龍之介の短編小説の題材にも取られている（『今昔物語集』にも同じ説話がある）。
sen.e: The story of "Imogayu (Broth with potatoes)"is also used as material for Ryunosuke AKUTAGAWA's short story ("Konjaku Monogatari Shu" also contains the same setsuwa).
The story of "Imogayu (Broth with potatoes)"is also used as material for Ryunosuke AKUTAGAWA's short story (but "Konjaku Monogatari Shu" contains the same setsuwa).
The story called "Imogayu" (Potato gruel) was used as the inspiration for a short story by Ryunosuke AKUTAGAWA (note however that the same story also appears in "Konjaku monogatari shu").
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 『宇治拾遺物語』に収録された説話の内容は、大別すると次の三種に分けられる。
sen.e: Setsuwa contained in "Uji Shui Monogatari" can be classified into three categories by their contents.
The setsuwa contained in "Uji Shui Monogatari" can be classified into three categories according to their contents:
The setsuwa contained in "Uji Shui Monogatari" can be classified into three categories according to their contents:

sen.j: 仏教説話（破戒僧や高僧の話題、発心・往生談など）
sen.e: Buddhist setsuwa (topics on depraved priest or venerable priest, story of religious awakening or death, etc.)
Buddhist setsuwa (topics on depraved priests or venerable priests, stories of religious awakening or death, etc.)
Buddhist setsuwa (whose topics include depraved priests, venerable priests, spiritual awakening, and passing into the next life)
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 世俗説話（滑稽談、盗人や鳥獣の話、恋愛話など）
sen.e: Secular setsuwa (funny stories, stories on robber or animals, love stories, etc.)
Secular setsuwa (funny stories, stories on robbers or animals, love stories, etc.)
Secular setsuwa (funny stories, stories on robbers or animals, love stories, etc.)

sen.j: 民間伝承（「雀報恩の事」など）
sen.e: Folklore (such as "story of a sparrow that returned a favor")
Folklore (such as "the story of a sparrow that returned a favor")
Secular setsuwa (including humorous tales, tales about robbers or animals, and love stories)
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 民間伝承には、「わらしべ長者」や「雀の恩返し」、「こぶとりじいさん」などなじみ深い説話が収められている。
sen.e: As folklores, well-known setsuwa such as "Warashibe Choja (literally, rich person by central stalk of a dried rice plant)," "Suzume no Ongaeshi (a sparrow that returned a favor)" and "Kobutori Jiisan (old man who got his wen snatched off)" are included.

As folklore, well-known setsuwa such as "Warashibe Choja (literally, rich person by the central stalk of a dried rice plant)," "Suzume no Ongaeshi (the sparrow that returned a favor)" and "Kobutori Jiisan (the old man who got his wen snatched off)" are included.

As folklore, well-known setsuwa such as 'Warashibe Choja' (literally, rich person by the central stalk of a dried rice plant), 'Suzume no Ongaeshi '(the sparrow that returned a favor) and 'Kobutori Jiisan' (the old man who got his wen snatched off) are included.

sen.j: 仏教に関する説話も含むが、どちらかというと猥雑、ユーモラスな話題（比叡山の稚児が幼さゆえの場違いな発言で僧侶の失笑を買う、等）が多く、教訓や啓蒙の要素は薄い。
sen.e: Although it contains certain number of setsuwa concerning Buddhism, many setsuwa are related to bawdy or humorous topics (for example, a chigo of Mt. Hiei invited sniggers of priests because of his words improper for the occasion caused by his immaturity) and elements of moral lesson or enlightenment are not so much.

Although it contains a certain number of setsuwa concerning Buddhism, many setsuwa are related to bawdy or humorous topics (for example, a chigo of Mt. Hiei invited the sniggering of priests because of his words were improper for the occasion, caused by his immaturity) but there are relatively few elements involving moral lessons or enlightenment.

Although the collection does include some tales with Buddhist subject matter, most such tales tend to be on bawdy or humorous topics (for example, one features a chigo (acolyte) of Mt. Hiei who becomes the laughingstock of the priests when his youthful inexperience leads him to speak in a manner inappropriate to the occasion), and didactic or morally instructive elements are relatively weak in such tales.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: すなわち、信仰に導きたいというような特定の価値観に拘束されない自由な視点で説話と関わる姿勢が覗われる。
sen.e: Namely, we can figure out the attitude to treat setsuwa from the free viewpoint not bound to any specific sense of worth, such as to lead to religious faith.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: Consequently, we can approach the setsuwa from a free perspective not bound to any specific sense of worth, such as that of a particular religious faith.
Consequently, it is possible to approach the setsuwa in this collection from a point of view that is unfettered by allegiance to any specific code of values that would require a faith-based reading.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: その意味において、中世説話集の中でも特異な存在である。
sen.e: In that sense, it is unique one among setsuwashu of the medieval times.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: In that sense, it is unique one among the setsuwashu of medieval times.
In that sense, among all the medieval collections of setsuwa tales this one stands out as unique.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 『宇治拾遺物語』は、1213年（建保元年）から1221年（承久三年）頃にかけて成立したらしい。
sen.e: It seems that "Uji Shui Monogatari" was formed in the period from 1213 to 1221.
It seems that "Uji Shui Monogatari" was compiled during the period from 1213 to 1221.
It seems that "Uji Shui Monogatari" was compiled during the period from 1213 to 1221.

sen.j: 序文では、この説話集の成立の経過について、次のようなことが書かれている。
sen.e: Its preface includes the following descriptions about the process of its formation.
Its preface includes the following descriptions about the process of its compilation.
Its preface includes the following descriptions about the process of its compilation.

sen.j: 一、まず、「宇治大納言」と呼ばれた貴族、隆国によって書かれたという『宇治大納言物語』が成立した（現在は散佚）。
sen.e: 1. At first, "Ujidainagon Monogatari" reportedly written by a noble called "Ujidainagon", Takakuni, was formed (not existing now).
1. At first, "Ujidainagon Monogatari," reportedly written by the noble Takakuni under the title "Ujidainagon," was formed (though it is no longer in existence).
1. Firstly, the "Ujidainagon monogatari," supposedly written by the nobleman Takakuni--who called it simply "Ujidainagon"--was written (it is no longer extant).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 二、その後、『宇治大納言物語』が加筆・増補される。
sen.e: 2. Then, "Ujidainagon Monogatari" was revised and supplemented.
2. "Ujidainagon Monogatari" was then revised and supplemented.
2. "Ujidainagon Monogatari" was then revised and supplemented.

sen.j: 三、この物語に漏れた話、その後の話などを拾い集めた拾遺集が編まれた。
sen.e: 3. Shuishu was compiled by collected stories not taken into it and later stories.
3. Shuishu was compiled with collected stories not previously collected, as well as newer stories.

3. The Shuishu (which after all means "Collected Gleanings") was compiled from stories that had either not been included in earlier compilations or had arisen after those other compilations were completed.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: いずれにしても、成立について諸説ある。
sen.e: Anyhow, there are several different views about its formation.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: At any rate, there are several different views regarding its formation.
At any rate, there are several different views regarding its formation.

sen.j: 『古事談』を直接の出典としている話が包含されていることにより、その成立期である建暦期であるとする説がある。
sen.e: As it contains a story, for which "Kojidan" is direct source, there is a view that the time of formation is the Kenryaku era (1211 - 1212).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: As it contains a story for which "Kojidan" is the direct source, there is a view that the period of its compilation is the Kenryaku era (1211 - 1212).
One theory holds that, because the "Kojidan" is thought to be the direct source for one of its tales, the Shuishu must have been compiled sometime during the Kenryaku era (1211-1212).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 第159話に「後鳥羽院」という諡号が出てくるのでこの「おくり名」が出された仁治3年（1242年）以後まもなく、とする説もある。
sen.e: As the shigo (a posthumous name) "Gotobain (Retired Emperor Gotoba)" appears in the 159th story, there is a view that the time of formation is soon after 1242, when this "okurina (posthumous name)" was announced.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: As the shigo (a posthumous name) "Gotobain (Retired Emperor Gotoba)" appears in the 159th story, there is a view that the time of formation is soon after 1242, when this "okurina (posthumous name)" was announced.

Another theory holds that the use of "Gotoba-in" (Retired Emperor Gotoba), the emperor's posthumous name, in story number 159 proves it must have been compiled soon after 1242, when this posthumous name first came into use.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 現存の『宇治拾遺物語』はこうして成立したらしいが、三がさらに抄出された版であるという見方もなされている。
sen.e: It seems that the presently existing "Ujishui Monogatari" was formed in that way, but there is another view that the present one is a version formed by digesting one described in above 3.
It seems that the currently existing "Ujishui Monogatari" was formed that way, but there is another view that the present one is a version formed by digesting one described in the above item 3.

A third point of view acknowledges that the currently extant "Uji shui monogatari" may well have been compiled as described above, but holds that the currently extant version represents only excerpts of the version described in number 3 above.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 一方で、この序文自体が編者もしくは後世の創作であるとする説もある。
sen.e: On the other hand, there is a view that the preface itself is a fiction by the compiler or in the later times.
However, there is a view that the preface itself is a piece of fiction by the compiler or someone in later times.
On the other hand, a competing theory argues that the preface itself was created and then added by the compiler or perhaps an editor of a later generation.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 二十数種の伝本があり、古本系と流布本系に大別される。
sen.e: There are more than twenty different types of denpon (existant books of transcription and published books) and they are roughly classified into old book group and rufu-bon (widely circulated edition) group.

There are more than 20 different types of denpon (existent books of transcription and published books), and they are roughly classified into the old book group and the rufu-bon (widely circulated edition) group.

Today more than twenty different denpon (transcribed or published manuscript versions) are extant; they can be broken into two general categories, the kohonkei (old book lineage) and the rufubonkei (widely circulated edition lineage).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 前者は宮内庁書陵部御所本が代表的な伝本。
sen.e: For the former, Kunaicho Shoryobu Goshobon (book retained by the Archives and Mausoleum Department of the Imperial Household Agency) is the typical denpon.
For the former, Kunaicho Shoryobu Goshobon (a book retained by the Archives and Mausoleum Department of the Imperial Household Agency) is the typical denpon.

The most representative denpon of the former category is the Kunaicho Shoryobu Goshobon (in other words, "the manuscript kept by the Archives and Mausoleum Department of the Imperial Household Agency").
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 後者は万治二年板本で、挿絵入りで、内閣文庫他に現存する。
sen.e: The latter is the Manji Ninen Han Bon (edition of 1659) which is illustrated and exists in the Cabinet Library, etc.
The latter is the Manji Ninen Han Bon (edition of 1659), which is illustrated and exists in the Cabinet Library, etc.

The best example of the latter lineage is the Manji Ninen Han Bon ("the version published in Manji 2," or in other words the 1659 edition) an illustrated version which can still be found in the Cabinet Library, among other places.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。
